@noahwesley And conversely, the best designers I've worked with could hack around in the code base without too much hand-holding. Worth their weight in gold.
which was super uncool at the time but now is super cool!
yay

much better
wow, I'm glad Faruk mentioned that developers also need to design

uuuuuugh
Hehe. Chrome verison: 12.0.742.112, Major, minor, point, build. Bleh.
I think there are use cases for only supporting really new browsers
@johnbellone point svn revision
like if you're designing an app targeted at early adopters
why bother with old browsers for early adopters?
leah: One use case is being able to decide who you want your customers to be.
@leah Support standards, not browsers.
it's pretty easy to collect data on what browsers users are using, it's kind of a moot point, just see what users tell you then make a decision to support or not
@leah My side project hasn't been looked at in IE in quite some time. It might be costing me some customers, but I'm not totally sold that they're customers I'd actually want.
@johnbellone do IE users not pay? :P
cheap jerks
@johnbellone They would, I assume. But unless I can charge them more, I'm not going to be getting the same return given how much more I have to work to support them
Until this side project becomes the main project, I have to prioritize. That means easy wins with the greatest return.
There is no such thing as a web developer that isn't a designer IMO. If you think you are you're probably a backend engineer :)
I think the best products come from teams where everyone has the opportunity to design
The best web developers I've worked with know they aren't web designers or UX designers. :)

@leah Unfortunately, yes. I'd prefer having an actual DBA do a database design depending on what the use cases are. Or else you get this jumbled mess that I have to work with (database from the 1980s)
@montabe Agreed. They need to know how to do basic things in a pinch.
@leah me too! Then c++.
mine was javascript
It can't be a stage without a guitar.

I can do css in a pinch if needed, but not my best. I prefer digging into code. If it needs to be done it needs to be done.

@johnbellone Awesome. I'm the guy in a bright gold WVU polo (went with easy-to-spot today)

The story about that house is awesome.
@montabe Definitely, next break I'll see you in the lounge.
@littlelazer Choose what you're good at, what you want to learn, what will get it done quickly. Minimum Viable Product.
The best thing I learned about presentations from Faruk and Leah today: have a good first and last slide. You'll spend a lot of time there.
@montabe I was looking at that when you first put it up. Got some ideas you've probably already thought of, but I'd like to hear about it later.
@johnbellone I'm all ears when it comes to ideas ... even one's I've already heard or thought of (because it helps me figure out where to go next)
@neven I took a screenshot of that just to make sure it lives forever.
@KuraFire Great talk btw, seriously.
I must note that Ethan is currently making the exact face from his speaker photo on the re:build website.

Just realized I forgot to mention what my side project is: http://montabe.com, a photo aggregation service. An example is up on the monitor in the hack lounge (or available here: http://rebuildconf.montabe.com/galleries/re-build-2011?display=wall)
Regarding the Winchester Mystery House, and oh my god I can't believe I'm saying this, Swamp Thing #45 (the Alan Moore comic) is a pretty neat story about it. #pocketprotector
@KuraFire you ha a whole lot of technologies on that one slide that we should know to some extent, but how do we choose which ones? It's hard to know them all equally well.
@littlelazer (If I can bump in: I would suggest choosing the ones that make the most sense in your project! Plus a wildcard or two to keep yourself on your toes :)
@littlelazer focus on the ones most relevant to the work you do.
@johnbellone plus one you aren't so good at but still applicable. Stretch yourself.
@swilliams_et (Agreed. Adding geolocation to, uh, a web app for code snippets maybe isn't a great idea, but give it a shot if you've got time! Who knows!)

@neven Awesome takeaway.

;-)
@neven Maybe not Geolocation, but there’s definitely good things to explore with SVG or Canvas on a code snippets site!
